article.h1: First Light Measurements of Capella with the Low Energy Transmission Grating Spectrometer aboard the Chandra X-ray Observatory

span.span: A.C.Â Brinkman, C.J.T.Â Gunsing, J.S.Â Kaastra, R.L.J.Â vanÂ derÂ Meer, R.Â Mewe, F.Â Paerels 11affiliation: Present address, Columbia University, New York, NY, USA , A.J.J.Â Raassen 22affiliation: Also at Astronomical Institute â€Anton Pannekoekâ€, KruislaanÂ 403, 1098Â SJÂ Â Amsterdam, The Netherlands , J.J.Â vanÂ Rooijen
Space Research Organization of the Netherlands (SRON), SorbonnelaanÂ 2, 3584Â CAÂ Â Utrecht, TheÂ Netherlands
H.Â BrÃ¤uninger, W.Â Burkert, V.Â Burwitz, G.Â Hartner, P.Â Predehl
Max-Planck-Institut fÃ¼r Extraterrestrische Physik (MPE), PostfachÂ 1603, D-85740Â Garching, Germany
UniversitÃ¤t Hamburg, GojenbergswegÂ 122, D-21029 Hamburg, Germany
J.J.Â Drake, O.Â Johnson, M.Â Juda, V.Â Kashyap, S.S.Â Murray, D.Â Pease, P.Â Ratzlaff, B.J.Â Wargelin
Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, 60Â Garden Street, Cambridge, MAÂ 02138, USA

div.p: We present the first X-ray spectrum obtained by the Low Energy Transmission Grating Spectrometer (LETGS) aboard the Chandra X-ray Observatory. The spectrum is of Capella and covers a wavelength range of 5â€“175Â Ã…Â (2.5â€“0.07Â keV). The measured wavelength resolution, which is in good agreement with ground calibration, is Î”â¢Î»â‰ƒsimilar-to-or-equalsÎ”ğœ†absentDelta italic-lambda RELOP:similar-to-or-equals\Delta\lambda\simeq 0.06Â Ã…Â (FWHM). Although in-flight calibration of the LETGS is in progress, the high spectral resolution and unique wavelength coverage of the LETGS are well demonstrated by the results from Capella, a coronal source rich in spectral emission lines. While the primary purpose of this letter is to demonstrate the spectroscopic potential of the LETGS, we also briefly present some preliminary astrophysical results. We discuss plasma parameters derived from line ratios in narrow spectral bands, such as the electron density diagnostics of the He-like triplets of carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen, as well as resonance scattering of the strong FeÂ XVII line at 15.014Â Ã….

article.div: instrumentation: spectrographs â€” line: identification â€” plasmas â€” stars: individual (Capella) â€” stars: coronae â€” X-rays: stars

div.p: The LETGS consists of three components of the Chandra Observatory: the High Resolution Mirror Assembly (HRMA) (VanÂ Speybroeck et al., 1997), the Low Energy Transmission Grating (LETG) (Brinkman et al., 1987, 1997; Predehl et al., 1997), and the spectroscopic array of the High Resolution Camera (HRC-S) (Murray et al., 1997). The LETG, designed and manufactured in a collaborative effort of SRON in the Netherlands and MPE in Germany, consists of a toroidally shaped structure which supports 180Â grating modules. Each module holds three 1.5-cmÂ diameter grating facets which have a line density of 1008Â lines/mm. The three flat detector elements of the HRC-S, each 10Â cm long and 2Â cm wide, are tilted to approximate the Rowland focal surface at all wavelengths, assuring a nearly coma-free spectral image. The detector can be moved in the cross-dispersion direction and along the optical axis, to optimize the focus for spectroscopy. 111 Further information on LETGS components is found in the AXAF Observatory Guide (http://asc.harvard.edu/udocs/) and at the Chandra X-ray Center calibration webpages (http://asc.harvard.edu/cal/).

An image of the LETG spectrum is focused on the HRC-SÂ with zeroth order at the focus position and dispersed positive and negative orders symmetric on either side of it. The dispersion is 1.15Â Ã…/mm in first spectral order. The spectral width in the cross-dispersion direction is minimal at zeroth order and increases at larger wavelengths due to the intrinsic astigmatism of the Rowland circle spectrograph. The extraction of the spectrum from the image is done by applying a spatial filter around the spectral image and constructing a histogram of counts vs. position along the dispersion direction. The background is estimated from areas on the detector away from the spectral image and can be reduced by filtering events by pulse-height.

Capella is a binary system at a distance of 12.9Â pc consisting of G8 and G1 giants with an orbital period of 104Â days (Hummel et al., 1994). It is the brightest quiescent coronal X-ray source in the sky after the Sun, and is therefore an obvious line source candidate for first light and for instrument calibration. X rays from Capella were discovered in 1975 (Catura, Acton, & Johnson, 1975; Mewe et al., 1975) and subsequent satellite observations provided evidence for a multi-temperature component plasma (e.g. Mewe (1991) for references). Recent spectra were obtained with EUVE longward of 70Â Ã…Â with a resolution of about 0.5Â Ã…Â (Dupree et al., 1993; Schrijver et al., 1995).

The LETG First Light observation of Capella was performed on 6Â September 1999 (00h27m UT â€“ 10h04m UT) with LETG and HRC-S. For the analysis we use a composite of six observations obtained in the week after first light, with a total observing time of 95Â ksec. The HRC-SÂ output was processed through standard pipeline processing. For LETG/HRC-SÂ events, only the product of the wavelength and diffraction order is known because no diffraction order information can be extracted. Preliminary analysis of the pipeline output immediately revealed a beautiful line-rich spectrum. The complete background-subtracted, negative-order spectrum between 5Â and 175Â Ã…Â is shown in Fig.Â 1.
Line identifications were made using previously measured and/or theoretical wavelengths from the literature. The most prominent lines are listed in TableÂ 1.

The spectral resolution Î”â¢Î»Î”ğœ†Delta italic-lambda\Delta\lambda of the LETGS is nearly constant when expressed in wavelength units, and therefore the resolving power Î»/Î”â¢Î»ğœ†Î”ğœ†italic-lambda MULOP:divide Delta italic-lambda\lambda/\Delta\lambda is greatest at long wavelengths. With the current uncertainty of the LETGS wavelength scale of about 0.015Â Ã…, this means that the prominent lines at 150Â and 171Â Ã…Â could be used to measure Doppler shifts as small as 30Â km/sec, such as may occur during stellar-flare mass ejections, once the absolute wavelength calibration of the instrument has been established. This requires, however, that line rest-frame wavelengths are accurately known and that effects such as the orbital velocity of the Earth around the Sun are taken into account. Higher-order lines, such as the strong O VIII LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha line at 18.97Â Ã…, which is seen out to 6th order, can also be used.

A quantitative analysis of the entire spectrum by multi-temperature fitting or differential emission measure modeling yields a detailed thermal structure of the corona, but this requires accurate detector efficiency calibration which has not yet been completed. However, some diagnostics based on intensity ratios of lines lying closely together can already be applied. In this letter we consider the helium-like line diagnostic and briefly discuss the resonance scattering in the FeÂ XVII 15.014Â Ã…Â line.

Electron densities, nesubscriptğ‘›ğ‘’italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{e}, can be measured using density-sensitive spectral lines originating from metastable levels, such as the forbiddenÂ (fğ‘“italic-ff) 23â¢Sâ†’11â¢Sâ†’superscript23ğ‘†superscript11ğ‘†NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-S ARROW:to NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-S2^{3}S\to 1^{1}S line in helium-like ions. This line and the associated resonanceÂ (rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr) 21â¢Pâ†’11â¢Sâ†’superscript21ğ‘ƒsuperscript11ğ‘†NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-P ARROW:to NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-S2^{1}P\to 1^{1}S and intercombinationÂ (iğ‘–italic-ii) 23â¢Pâ†’11â¢Sâ†’superscript23ğ‘ƒsuperscript11ğ‘†NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-P ARROW:to NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-S2^{3}P\to 1^{1}S line make up the so-called helium-like â€tripletâ€ lines (Gabriel & Jordan, 1969; Pradhan, 1982; Mewe, Gronenschild, & VanÂ denÂ Oord, 1985). The intensity ratio (i+f)/rğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘ŸOPEN:( italic-i ADDOP:plus italic-f CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-r(i+f)/r varies with electron temperature, T, but more importantly, the ratio i/fğ‘–ğ‘“italic-i MULOP:divide italic-fi/f varies with nesubscriptğ‘›ğ‘’italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{e} due to the collisional coupling between the 23â¢Ssuperscript23ğ‘†NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-S2^{3}S and 23â¢Psuperscript23ğ‘ƒNUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-P2^{3}P level.

The LETGS wavelength band contains the He-like triplets from C, N, O, Ne, Mg, and Si (âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 40, 29, 22, 13.5, 9.2, and 6.6Â Ã…, respectively). However, the Si and Mg triplets are not sufficiently resolved and the NeÂ IX triplet is too heavily blended with iron and nickel lines for unambiguous density analysis. The OÂ VII lines are clean (see Fig.Â 2) and the CÂ V and NÂ VI lines can be separated from the blends by simultaneous fitting of all lines. These triplets are suited to diagnose plasmas in the range nesubscriptğ‘›ğ‘’italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{e} = 1088FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{8}â€“101111FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{11}Â cm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3} and Tğ‘‡italic-TTÂ âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\simÂ 1â€“3Â MK. For the C, N, and O triplets the measured i/fğ‘–ğ‘“italic-i MULOP:divide italic-fi/f ratios are 0.38Â±0.14plus-or-minus0.380.14NUMBER:0.38 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.140.38\pm 0.14, 0.52Â±0.15plus-or-minus0.520.15NUMBER:0.52 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.150.52\pm 0.15, and 0.250Â±0.035plus-or-minus0.2500.035NUMBER:0.250 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.0350.250\pm 0.035, respectively, which imply (Pradhan, 1982) nesubscriptğ‘›ğ‘’italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{e} (in 109superscript109NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{9}Â cm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}) = 2.8Â±1.3plus-or-minus2.81.3NUMBER:2.8 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1.32.8\pm 1.3, 6Â±3plus-or-minus63NUMBER:6 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:36\pm 3, and â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssimÂ 5 (1Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma upper limit), respectively, for typical temperatures as indicated by the (i+f)/rğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘ŸOPEN:( italic-i ADDOP:plus italic-f CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-r(i+f)/r ratios of 1, 1, and 3Â MK, respectively. This concerns the lower temperature part of a multi-temperature structure which also contains a hot (âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim6â€“8Â MK), and dense (â‰³greater-than-or-equivalent-toRELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to\gtrsimÂ 101212FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{12}Â cm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}) compact plasma component (see SectionÂ 3.2). The derived densities are comparable to those of active regions on the Sun with a temperature of a fewÂ MK. Fig.Â 2 shows a fit to the OÂ VII triplet measured in the â€“1Â order. The He-like triplet diagnostic, which was first applied to the Sun (e.g., Acton et al. (1972); Wolfson, Doyle, & Phillips (1983)) has now for the first time been applied to a star other than the Sun.

The long-wavelength region of the LETGS between 90Â and 150Â Ã…Â contains a number of density-sensitive lines from 2â¢â„“2â„“NUMBER:2 ell2\ellâ€“2â¢â„“â€²2superscriptâ„“â€²NUMBER:2 ell POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end2\ell^{\prime} transitions in the Fe-L ions FeÂ XXâ€“XXII which provide density diagnostics for relatively hot (â‰³greater-than-or-equivalent-toRELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to\gtrsimÂ 5Â MK) and dense (â‰³greater-than-or-equivalent-toRELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to\gtrsimÂ 101212FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{12}Â cm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}) plasmas (Mewe, Gronenschild, & VanÂ denÂ Oord, 1985; Mewe, Lemen, & Schrijver, 1991; Brickhouse, Raymond & Smith, 1995). These have been applied in a few cases to EUVE spectra of late-type stars and in the case of Capella have suggested densities more than two orders of magnitude higher than found here for cooler plasma (Dupree et al., 1993; Schrijver et al., 1995). These diagnostics will also be applied to the LETGS spectrum as soon as the long-wavelength efficiency calibration is established.

section.h3: 3.2 The 15â€“17Â Ã…Â region: resonance scattering of FeÂ XVII?

div.p: Transitions in Ne-like FeÂ XVII yield the strongest emission lines in the range 15â€“17Â Ã…Â (cf. Fig.Â 1). In principle, the optical depth, Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau, in the 15.014Â Ã…Â line can be obtained by applying a simplified escape-factor model to the ratio of the FeÂ XVIIÂ 15.014Â Ã…Â resonance line with a large oscillator strength to a presumably optically thin FeÂ XVII line with a small oscillator strength. We use the 15.265Â Ã…Â line because the 16.780Â Ã…Â line can be affected by radiative cascades (Liedahl, 1999). Solar physicists have used this technique to derive the density in active regions on the Sun (e.g., Saba et al. (1999); Phillips et al. (1996, 1997)).

Various theoretical models predict 15.014/15.265Â ratio values in the range 3.3â€“4.7 with only a slow variation (â‰²less-than-or-similar-toRELOP:less-than-or-similar-to\lesssimÂ 5%) with temperature or energy in the region 2â€“5Â MK or 0.1â€“0.3Â keV (Brown et al., 1998; Bhatia & Doschek, 1992). The fact that most ratios observed in the Sun typically range from 1.5â€“2.8 (Brown et al. (1998), and references above), significantly lower than the theoretical ratios, supports claims that in solar active regions the 15.014Â Ã…Â line is affected by resonant scattering. The 15.014/15.265Â ratio which was recently measured in the Livermore Electron Beam Ion Trap (EBIT) (Brown et al., 1998) and ranges from 2.77â€“3.15 (with individual uncertainties of about Â±0.2plus-or-minus0.2ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.2\pm~{}0.2) at energies between 0.85â€“1.3Â keV, is significantly lower than calculated values. Although the EBIT results do not include probably minor contributions from processes such as dielectronic recombination satellites and resonant excitation, this may imply that the amount of solar scattering has been overestimated in past analyses. Our measured ratio FeÂ XVIII 16.078Â Ã…/FeÂ XVII 15.265Â Ã…Â gives a temperature of âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim6Â MK and the photon flux ratio 15.014/15.265 is measured to be 2.64Â±0.10plus-or-minus0.10ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.10\pm 0.10. If we compare this to the recent EBIT results we conclude that there is little or no evidence for opacity effects in the 15.014Â Ã…Â line seen in our Capella spectrum.

The Capella measurements with LETGS show a rich spectrum with excellent spectral resolution (Î”â¢Î»â‰ƒsimilar-to-or-equalsÎ”ğœ†absentDelta italic-lambda RELOP:similar-to-or-equals\Delta\lambda\simeq0.06Â Ã…, FWHM). About 150Â lines have been identified of which the brightest hundred are presented in TableÂ 1. The high-resolution spectra of the Chandra grating spectrometers allow us to carry out direct density diagnostics, using the He-like triplets of the most abundant elements in the LETGS-band, which were previously only possible for the Sun. Density estimates based on C, N and O He-like complexes indicate densities typical of solar active regions and some two or more orders of magnitude lower than density estimates for the hotter (>RELOP:greater-than>5Â MK) plasma obtained from EUVE spectra. A preliminary investigation into the effect of resonance scattering in the FeÂ XVII line at 15.014Â Ã…Â showed no clear evidence for opacity effects. After further LETGS in-flight calibration it is expected that relative Doppler velocities of the order of 30Â km/s will be detectable at the longest wavelengths.

section.div: The LETGS data as presented here could only be produced after dedicated efforts of many people for many years. Our special gratitude goes to the technical and scientific colleagues at SRON, MPE and their subcontractors for making such a superb LETG and to the colleagues at many institutes for building the payload. Special thanks goes to the many teams who made Chandra a success, particularly the project scientist team, headed by Dr. Weisskopf, the MSFC project team, headed by Mr. Wojtalik, the TRW industrial teams and their subcontractors, the Chandra observatory team, headed by Dr. Tananbaum, and the crew of Space Shuttle flight STS-93. JJD, OJ, MJ, VK, SSM, DP, PR, and BJW were supported by Chandra X-ray Center NASA contract NAS8-39073 during the course of this research.

img.figcaption: Figure 1: The complete LETGS spectrum of Capella, split into three parts for clarity. Note the difference in x and y scale for the three parts. Indicated in the plot are the triplets discussed in the text and a selection of the Fe lines at longer wavelengths. The hundred strongest lines are listed in TableÂ 1.

Figure 2: The Oxygen VII triplet in the LETGS â€“1Â order spectrum with the resonanceÂ (r), the forbiddenÂ (f), and the intercombinationÂ (i) line. The measured ratios of these lines (from the fitted curve) are given in the text.

figure.figcaption: Table 1: Comparison of measured and theoretical values of the strongest lines in the Capella spectrum as shown in Fig.Â 1.
